results.title: The Agrarian revolution
results.creator_credit: Hugh Baddeley Productions and W. Hugh Baddeley
results.brief_description: Deals with the enclosure of common lands, one of the most dramatic happenings in British history, and describes the changes in agriculture over the last two hundred and fifty years. Commentary by spoken by Dick Graham.

results.title: The Agony of Jimmy Quinlan
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Peter Katadotis, Robert Duncan, Janice H Brown and Andy Thomson
results.brief_description: Jimmy Quinlan is a derelict, one of some five thousand other men and women who have abandoned their jobs and families to live in the streets and alleys in Montreal. This film, a powerful portrayal of life on skid row, tells of his “agonies” - his attempt to get off the bottle. It’s something he’s tried before, and will probably have to try again. Award: New York

results.title: The Ageing of the lakes
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and John Walker
results.brief_description: Explains the process of the natural ageing and eventual death of lakes, called eutrophication. Also links man’s environmental interference with the changes in the lakes and investigates current efforts to retard eutrophication and preserve and restore lakes in America. Discusses pollution and methods for its control.

results.title: The Age of revolutions: W. Blake, poet and painter
results.creator_credit: Open University, BBC-TV and Edward Hayward
results.brief_description: Relates two sides of Blake’s work which are normally considered separately - his art, particularly his illustrations, and his poetry. Concentrates on “Songs of Innocence and Experience” and the much closer relationship between text and illustrations than usually admitted. The delicate colours of the illustrations, often no more than half an inch across, are shown in close-up.

results.title: The Age of plywood
results.brief_description: The manufacture and uses of plywood. Every stage in the manufacture of plywood, from the journey of the log from the forest, its peeling or slicing into veneer, and processing to various grades of plywood. The uses of plywood in homes, commercial buildings and building projects, for panelling, furniture, structural work, concrete formwork and boat building.

results.title: The Age of innocence [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Cappa, De Fina, Barbara de Fina and Martin Scorsese
results.brief_description: Trapped within New York’s 19th Century high society, a time of lavish excess and social hypocrisy, Newland Archer (Daniel Day-Lewis) is caught between two women and two worlds - his lovely fiancee May Welland (Winona Ryder) and the world he knows, and the scandalous Countess Olenska (Michelle Pfeiffer) and the world he dreams of having. Based on Edith Wharton’s Pulitzer Prize winning novel, “The Age of innocence” is the quintessential story of forbidden love, luminous with passion, temptation, intrigue and sacrifice. Also available on VHS [305955].

results.title: The Age of Aquarius
results.brief_description: This survey of the lifestyles of the young focuses on three communes, each of which represents its search for a new way because their lives have been meaningless and empty. The narrator points out that young people believe their search for The Age of Aquarius will save them, if not mankind, from society’s destruction.

results.title: The Age of 14 or 15 = Shi si wu sui
results.creator_credit: Beijing Children's Film Company and Zhao Yuan
results.brief_description:
Over the past hundred years, the age of 14 has become an extremely influential period in the average educated Chinese person’s life. In Europe, the US or Australia, a whole genre of films have sought to capture this right of passage in a young person’s life, where they explore their changing bodies, their own sense of identity and the world of ideas and morality. But these experiences don’t even count for small change in China.

A boarding school filled with young adults might invite these connotations in Western countries, however we are shown this period is influential for completely different reasons in the PRC. The beginning of junior high means the pressure is really on: From this moment on, the young teens face extreme competition with one another in order to excel in their studies and make the grade for the best possible high-school, which is the only way of standing a chance at university admission.

It is therefore a period of both extreme tension and vigorous excitement. No longer treated as children, these young adults feel that they have been invested with the responsibility for their own fate. However, the film also highlights the commonplace attitude — especially among children from rural areas — where they vow to commit suicide if they do not achieve the necessary grade for the best high school.

With this said, we might expect the schools to be churning out utter monsters. Quite the opposite, in fact. Indeed, the extreme pressure and excitement of this time inspires a deep sense of cameraderie between them, as they recognise that they are not alone in their struggle. Of course, competition always manages to bring out the worst antisocial traits in a select few, but the group overall are seen to flourish, often going to great pains to stick their neck out for each other.

The film explains the powerful bond made between friends and classmates of these years, and how struggle is not only a necessary part of life, but teaches us how to empathise with others and work together. The contemporary view of this film is more likely to equate to something like: Harry Potter, with no magic, in Communist China.

Among the film’s many themes it examines antisocial personality traits, with plenty of cheating in basketball games, skirting labor, cherrypicking others’ praise, taking advantage of the latitudes of the system, etc. However, we are expected to understand that, in all these situations, it is the Truth which shines through in the long run to reveal people’s true intentions and motives.

Although the children are shown to celebrate their 14th year, it would be more realistic to see this as an expression of general nostalgia for those who have left those more simple times behind. The film, therefore, advocates that this is the time young people should appreciate fully the joy of being alive before moving on to a glorious future (something that any young person can expect to be told by their elders).
(3 stars - James Donald; June 10, 2011)

results.title: The Afternoon house
results.brief_description: An experimental film showing the fascination of an old house and its garden for a small girl. She goes there to retrieve a lost ball, and wanders about looking at the trees and flowers first, and then going through the Georgian doorway and up the staircase exploring the rooms, looking at the pictures, trying an old fashioned cane chair and then, becoming engrossed in her surroundings, she knocks over a vase of daisies and is frightened as she sees ugly masks staring at her from the walls. She dashes downstairs and out the gate without stopping even to retrieve her ball. Photographed by Mike Browning, music by Allan Lee.

results.title: The African scene: youth builds a nation in Tanzania
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films, Visual Education Center, Toronto and H Lemieux
results.brief_description: Emphasises the importance of “nation-building” by showing girls of a government-operated secondary school in Tanzania helping their country to develop a better standard of living. Also shows use of co-operative farming as a means of increasing agricultural production and improving rural life.
